caption: Great photo museum with a lot of temporary exhibition, in fact this museum only have temporary exhibitions often coupled with presentations in the emphiteatre at the ground floor. There are always at least two differents exhibitions at the same time. Definitely worth a visit if you stay more then two weeks in Paris

I so enjoyed visiting here with my mum. The exhibitions are digestible, well designed and fascinating. The staff were very patient and helpful to us, and it's not too crowded, even on a weekend in July.

The MEP in central Paris futures a rather small based exhibition, unexpected considering the enormous amount of (photo, film, and data) material reserved. The aftermath of the visit will be surprising as however the experience is great, and beyond expectations.
Great exhibitions on many floors all linked to one theme

Defenitly a must go if you are interested in Photography. They have great exhibitions of various artists and there is always at least one you haven't heard of. They present the images in a very professional and original way and don't forget to buy one or two photography books in the library, the have a large selection of them.

A big deception. Been here before 10 years ago, then it was much more interesting. This August I went and left with an empty hole in my stomach... And pocket. Hope they catch up with more interesting things. Otherwise this place wont last much longer, i assume.

You should definitely go to MEP whenever you visit Paris. Their exhibition and photographs will touch your mind and heart. I went to their ‚ÄúLove Songs‚Äù exhibition which talked about intimacy and love.

Whenever in Paris always go to the MEP and it's always good to be back. The building is interesting and there are always more or less good exhibitions.  Now I saw the retrospective of work by Samuel Fosso which was a very personal overview from his work with sometimes a lot of humor  Although the best part of the exhibition for me was the lively 21 min dance video Swinguerra from Barbara Wagner and Benjamin de Burca (2019)

This was a very disappointing visit. The exhibition of Boris Mikhailov, although very depressing, was interesting and well organized, but it took up 2 floors and was overkill with more than 800 images. The biggest problem, however, was that almost none of the 24,000 photographs in their own collection were on display. There is only one tiny room with about a dozen photographs, nothing else.
Great little museum of contemporary photography. The two exhibitions we saw were pretty avant garde so don't expect to see Cartier-Bresson.

As a passionate photographer i believe that this museum was one of the best discovery in Paris. 3 floors of exhibition of French and foreign photographer, different ideas, different styles and point of views. I recommend this museum, which is located in le marais quartier, it takes just 1/2 hours to be visited and if you like photography it's a must of your visit in Paris.

I loved it. The galleria isn‚Äôt that big, but very much worth visiting. There‚Äôs a small cafe and shop on the -1 level. Exhibitions vary, as far as I understand. I bought ticket on site, but it can be booked online as well. There was no queue on Sunday evening, but the rooms were quite crowded. Mostly locals
Very cool photography museum with great exhibitions

Before it used to be free on Wednesdays. I don't get why they changed that. Otherwise it's still very good. Always saw great photo exhibitions. And this Tahara's niwa garden is somptuous. What a great gift to welcome visitors.
A great place for photography, discovering new names and inspiration. Special thanks to the staff for the quality of the exhibitions! Beautiful book shop insideüôÜüèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è ‚Ä¶
Beautiful exhibitions, contemporary photography, contemporary art for that matter, at its BEST!
Got to the exhibition of Ukrainian photographer Boris Mikhailov.  in great delight.  thanks for the support of Ukraine
Great place if you like art & history, not only for photographers. I‚Äôm from Mexico and every time that I‚Äôm visiting Paris I‚Äôd like to visit museums and this one was one of my favorites.
Waste of time to come here.almost no photographs,rather a lot of so called sophisticated art installations. Boring.
Nice location, great exhibitions. I was hoping the Maltourn√©e exhibition would take up more space. Lawn on the first floor was very well maintained.

In my opinion the choice of the exhibition was poor. Although interesting, it was an exhibition about an exhibition, with no original work from the artist on display. Overall, the prestation is not as good as some other photo museum such as the Fotografiska in Stockholm. I'd still recommend the place.
I believe it's not worth the expense as I found the photo collection inside the museum to be underwhelming although in my opinion there was no photo inside for a photography museum.

SCAM - TOURIST TRAP - AVOID Their website has clearly stated that visitors under 30 are eligible for "reduced ticket", but when I was at the ticket office, they told me it is 25, not 30, if this is not a scam to lure visitors, I don't know what is. It is institution like this one trashing the reputation of Paris, destroying the tourism industry of France, NEVER would I visit this trap
It‚Äôs not big, and the exhibition are great

I recommend this place if you enjoy photography. They have interesting expositions, sometimes with specific and unusual themes, which change periodically. Totally worth it if you are taking a walk around the Marais.
Loved the current exhibits!  We stayed a very long time and enjoyed it thoroughly.
Amazing expo , high quality !
Attended screening of Frederick Wiseman film in theatre section.
My favourite museum in Paris. 4 exhibitions each time so you will always find one that suits you

This museum is a terrific destination for photography buffs in general and studio photographers in particular. The exhibitions on display during our last visit were three prominent Japanese photographers, all pretty amazing and running the gamut from a relatively young inventive studio photographer To one of Japan‚Äôs revered post war photographers. The museum displays well over three floor and a little hidden basement gallery. It‚Äôs a value for everyone but particularly for seniors who get a fair discount. Overall, a good museum to put on your list for your next visit to Paris.
Worth checking what exposition are currently being exposed. Best photograph museum in Paris
A great space to exhibit European art, hid from the bustling Parisian central streets.

A place I often end up at when I am in a mood for a photo exhibition. Good artist curation, always good set up. Last exhibition I really enjoyed was Boris Mikhailov, Ukrainian and dissident photographer. Must see.

If you love photography, this is one of the best gallery to visit. The diversity and often changing exhibits do draw a lot of attention. The setting is perfect for an almost intimate viewing of the works. I always avoid the first couple of days of new shows for an even better experience.
Always √† pleasure being in this beautiful place with amazing exhibitions  My pic @jaklebanon
The collections trigger your thoughts and are inspiring. Different types if photographs for people interested in different things. Perfect experience for a rainy day.

A little small but great variety of exhibitions. Though I understand the context, can't say i was a fan of the recent Boris exhibition where purely amateurish photography was oversold as talented work.
It's rare to move someone's heart and inspire these days. This museum simply does the both of them.
An amazing exposition of Hassan Hajjaj a Moroccan and British photographer. A must see for everyone !

Just the size you need for an exposition. Everything is located on 2 floors so you don't spend hours wandering. Expo well chosen and organized. The small coffee shop outside add a delightful touch in summer.

Overall a nice museum and the price is ok for what you get. (at least for students, ‚Ç¨5)  For the photographs exhibited, I would have loved to have a more detailed information. Still very nice art pieces and big plus: it wasn't crowded at any point (went there at 6.30 pm)

For a European house of Photo it is rather small and visits are expensive. Also the choice of collections is disputable. We were confronted with the work of Zanele Muholi on two floors, one floor with her personal work revolting against her 40 years she spent as a maid of a white family and the 2nd floor as a gay person and the suffering of the community as a whole and she herself. It feels like the MEP is run by women and imposes the visitors to share their vision or at least win them over to like it. The small ground floor was also a female photographer who offered no relief in great photos. Personally I have seen much more interesting work from gay photographers at Breda Photo which touched the same subject but the organization left room for those who are beyond the gay problem photography. There are so many other subjects to take photos of that are equally important than the female gay problem. Let's talk about autism in France and how families with autistic children are treated by the government. I have seen beautiful pictures at Breda Photo that are much more engaging than a selfie of Muholi with a carpet on her head after being a gay maid for 40 years.

It always depends on the expositions hosted at the museum but generally they do have lots of food options if you are a fan of photography, student or just like museums. The guys at the entrance are so nice and they will help you with what you need. You can get an anual membership that is very cheap. Access by elevator for people with mobility problems. The entrance is 9‚Ç¨ full price or 4,50‚Ç¨ if you are a student, under 26, over 60... Just be sure to check the reductions at the entrance. Anyways, just make sure you go at least once, specially if you like photography

I went to this museum several times. Photographies are dispatched on 3 floors. The museum is "small size" I would say but the selection are always good and interesting. Little shop and also a cafe in the backyard!

Great space, well curated, interesting exhibits. Located in the Marais, easy access by metro or bus. The Maison also includes workshop spaces for activities in the cellar. There is a small but very pleasant cafe in an outdoor courtyard.

Jennifer's Top 10 Museums in Paris!  Totally underrated. Featuring amazing contemporary photographers. I was blown away by the work. Two floors of just absolute perfection. Come here often as they change up the collections. A must if you love photography.
Obviously brand new, very elegant and well displayed.... Definitely worth a look

Nice gallery in typical old Parisian big house. There‚Äôs a flat entry fee of ‚Ç¨9 (students and unwaged get a discount). Perhaps expensive compared to photographers gallery in london or similar where some parts are free and others paid for. However there were around 5 different artists covered - a few quite extensively.  I visited around 12.30 and the place wasn‚Äôt so busy. Which is good as I‚Äôm sure no one really appreciates a cramped and crowded gallery. Would visit again.
